div.l: For Iohn in faith I may be of your sort
I is as yll a Miller͗e as ar ye
This myller smyleth at her nycetee
And thought all this nys but for a wyle
They wene that no man may hem begyle
But by my thryft / yitte shall I blere hir yie
For al the sleight in her Philosophie
The more queynt crekes þat þey make
The more woll I stele whan I take
In stede of flour͗e yitte woll I yeve hem bren̄
The grettest clerkes ben̄ nat wisest men
As whilom̄ to the wolf þus spake þe mare
Of all her art / count I nat a tare
Out atte dore he goth ful p̉riuely
Whan that he sawe his tyme softly
He loketh vp and doun̄ till he hade found
The clerkes hors there it stode ybound
Behynd þe myll / vnder a leefsell
And to the hors / he goth hīm faire and well
And strepeth of the bridle right anon̄
And whan̄ the hors was loos / he gynneth to gon̄
Toward the fen̄ / there wild mares ren̄
And forth wᵗith we he/ þurgh thyk and then̄
This myller goth agayn̄ / no worde he seid
But doth his note and wᵗith the clerkes pleid
Tyll that her corn̄ was faire and wele yground
And whan the mele was sakked / and ybound
This Iohn goth out / and fynt his hors awey
Than gan̄ he to crye harrowe and weleawey
Our hors is lost Aleyn̄ / for goddes baonesbonesbanes
Step̄pe on̄ thy fete com̄ of man̄ all attanes
Allas our wardein has his palfray lorn̄
This Aleyn̄ all forgate both mele and corn̄
All was out of his mynd his husbondrye
What whilk way is he gaan̄ / he gan̄ krye
The wyf cam̄ lepyng inward wᵗith a renne
She seid allas yoʳur hors goth to þe fenne
Wᵗith wyld mares as fast as he may go
Vnthank com̄ on̄ his hondes þᵗat bonde hym so
And he that better shold haue knyt þe reyne
Allas koth Iohn Aleyn̄ for cristes peyne
